utterances: (As Viago) So it's 6 p.m. in the night time, which is when I wake up.

It's movies like this one that made New Zealand actor Sam Neill want to work with Taika Waititi.

Four vampires of various antiquity living in a - in a ghastly sort of student New Zealand apartment - just the kind of thing that I was in when I was at university, living in the same horrible conditions (laughter).
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""WHAT WE DO IN THE SHADOWS"")
(As Viago) Oh, it's a spinal column.
Yuck.
Waititi is half Maori, the indigenous people of New Zealand.
His 2010 film, ""Boy,"" centers around a group of Maori children in a poor coastal village, much like the one Waititi grew up in.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""BOY"")
(As Boy) I go to Raukokore school.
I have many favorite subjects, including art, social studies and Michael Jackson.
The boy in the film longs to have a relationship with his dad, a pot-smoking ex-convict.
Boy"" was a tremendous hit in New Zealand.
It was also nominated for an Oscar.
Waititi thinks part of its appeal was that it didn't perpetuate stereotypes.
And yeah, indigenous people in films - it's all, like, nose flutes and panpipes and, you know, people talking to ghosts and [expletive] and that, you know, which I hate.
So, you know, it's like we really wanted to throw that whole thing away.
Boy"" was quite an extraordinary film.
Again, actor Sam Neill.
I thought it the funniest thing I'd ever seen when I first saw it.
And then I saw it a second time.
I thought it was quite the saddest film I've ever seen.
In Waititi's new movie, that poignant humor is on full display.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""HUNT FOR THE WILDERPEOPLE"")
That's Annie Polland, chief historian at the synagogue.
She's taking me on a tour of the soaring space.
The main sanctuary is 70 feet high, lit by 67 stained-glass windows and countless brass and glass lamps.
The walls are covered with gold stars on a field of blue with tromploy(ph) curtains on either side of the art holding the Torah scrolls.
The majority of the people living in this neighborhood during the heyday of the congregation lived in tenement apartments.
And the streets were crowded.
And inside their work spaces and in their homes there was very little light, very few windows.
So to come into a building like this and the sense of space and the sense of light was really amazing.
We tried to talk about this as kind of an architectural Sabbath.
About walking through the building that the immigrant experienced a sense of otherness or a sense of the sacred and…
Who were the four progenitors of the entire Eldridge Street Synagogue?
How did it become established?
Well, there was - the congregation that built the synagogue was founded in 1852, and they were in a church that they had made into a synagogue, which was the norm at the time because…
Could you introduce us to those four people?
Yeah.
The founders that we know most about were Sender Jarmulowsky, who was a president of the congregation and he was a banker.
And he had come to New York in 1873 to open up a passage and exchange office on the corner of Canal and Orchard.
And David Cohen who was in real estate, and probably who was the one who scouted out the lots and found the architects.
Nathan Hutkoff who was in the plate glass building and perhaps had a link to the, you know, stained-glass windows that are here.
And Isaac Gellis who was -he started a kosher manufacturing business in the 1870s.
So the leaders had already established themselves in business and had the knowledge of how to navigate the courts, how to hire contractors, how to get this thing done.
And so this kind of nexus between business and Judaism that was - is the center of understanding how this place came to be.
Jews from all walks of life worshipped at Eldridge Street during its heyday - merchants, scholars and laborers packed the 740 seats.
Stars of the nearby Yiddish theaters were there.
Eddie Cantor came once, and 93-year-old Max Smith was bar mitzvah there in 1926.
His father had joined the congregation in 1903.
It was a lively synagogue, it was a bright synagogue.
There was (unintelligible) in those years, in fact, I remember the days when Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, I remember that there was standing-room only in the shul.
That's how packed it was.
Naomi Fuchs remembers in particular one pillar of the business community who attended services at Eldridge Street.
The fish, they was right along the Fulton Fish Market.
She had dressed beautiful with the (unintelligible) but did she smell from fish.
She sat in the front of the shul.
I still remember the smell.
But by the 1940s and 50s the fish market owner and her fellow worshippers were mostly gone, moved to the suburbs and unable to travel back into the city on the Sabbath.
The synagogue struggled financially.
When a hurricane blew out one of the grand rose windows it had to be replaced with plain-glass blocks.
In the 1950s the grand sanctuary was completely abandoned and for the next 25 years the few remaining worshippers held services in the basement.
Eventually an answered prayer: landmark status for the building.
By 1987 volunteers had raised enough money to begin restoration.
The first task was to dig a new basement underneath the existing crawl space so the old building could have modern conveniences like air conditioning.
And amid all the reconstruction perhaps the most labor-intensive work was restoration of the 67 stained-glass windows.
Workers pulled apart thousands of individual bits of stained glass to clean and reassemble them with new letting.
For Max Smith it was all worth the wait.
When they had the open house, I walked in and I saw the illumination and the beauty of the synagogue.
And immediately my brain brought me back to the days of old.
I'm not ashamed to say it.
My wife said it was amazing.
He started crying like a baby.
So I said, well, you have no idea.
It struck me so that my father was going to be there.
But unfortunately he wasn't there.
I felt very good because it really didn't happen to many shuls, you know.
They just closed down and, I'm telling you, my father didn't have to turn over in his grave.
He's really resting comfortably.
When we finish speaking, I ask Naomi Fuchs's husband, cantor Max Fuchs, to sing for us the same prayer he sang at the rededication of the synagogue.
The words mean God has preserved and sustained us to reach this happy day.
(Soundbite of singing)
(Singing) (Foreign language spoken)
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED, from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
The U.S.
Supreme Court heard arguments today in a case about the death penalty.
It tests what, if any, last minute legal challenges may be brought by a condemned man against the method of execution to be used to kill him.
The case involves a convicted cop killer named Clarence Hill, whose execution was stayed by the Supreme Court last January.
That stay came as Hill lay strapped to the gurney in Florida's death chamber.
NPR's Nina Totenberg reports.
Thirty years ago, death by lethal injection was conceived of as a more humane way to execute the condemned and 37 states now use that method.
But the lethal cocktail that's administered has not changed and critics charge that unnecessary suffering is caused by the drug combination and the lack of training for those who administer it.

The problem is that the anesthesia administered first is short-term and, as death penalty lawyer Todd Doss put it on the steps of the Supreme Court today, the paralytic administered next prevents the condemned man from indicating if he's still conscious and feeling while the lethal drug is administered.
